Open in a new tabThe cumulative incidence of brain tumors in DM patients accounting for competing mortality was: 1.3% (95%CI=0.6–2.3%) by age 50 years, 1.9% (95%CI=1.1–3.2%) by age 60, and 2.9% (95%CI=1.8–4.7%) by age 70 (Figure 1).

Figure 1:

Open in a new tab
Lifetime cumulative incidence of brain tumors and death in patients with myotonic dystrophySurvival patterns after the diagnosis of brain tumor:
The 3- and 5-year overall survival probabilities after brain tumor diagnosis in DM patients were: 65% (95% CI= 43–86%), and 52% (95%CI=29–75%), respectively (Figure 2).

Figure 2:

Open in a new tab
Survival patterns in myotonic dystrophy patients after brain tumor diagnosisDISCUSSION
Our study, based on updated follow-up of a Swedish DM cohort, and including all brain tumors regardless of the date of the first recorded DM clinical diagnosis, confirmed that brain tumors are part of the DM syndrome phenotype.
